name: Anonymous
com:
How to roll dice: "dice+2d6" without the quotes in the email field rolls 2d6. "dice+5d42+23" rolls 5d42+23. "noko+dice+2d6" rolls 2d6 without showing the roll in the email field.

In the rules department, you can look at http://www.4chan.org/rules - all global and board specific rules are in full effect. Apart from that, only two rules are important.

1. BE EXCELLENT TO EACH OTHER.
2. PARTY ON, DUDES. (AND DUDETTES)

com:
I've seen people on the 40k /k/ thread claim that the way the imperium (and other factions) fight is retarded. Like how vehicles such as the bandeblade are just massive sitting ducks for missiles and bunker busters, and how they are impractical/stupidly designed.

Plus emphasis on retarded melee combat, where most factions (except perhaps the tau) are guilty of.

Can the imperium (or other faction) beat a modern army in a conventional battle? No WMDs like nukes, orbital bombardment or exterminatus shit.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>>DRAWTHREAD RULES<<<

>Requesters:
• Provide good, detailed references (pictures are better than verbal descriptions), so the artists know what you're looking for.
• Only bump your request once every 24 hours. Don't bump WIPs.
• If you have a WIP quote the Anchor Post, and attach the WIP so your drawfag can find you.
• Do not reply to other deliveries with a request that the artist fill your request next, this is called 'piggybacking'.
• Do not make multiple requests in the same thread and do not serially request multiple characters after a delivery. Suggesting several concepts for artists to choose from counts as making multiple requests.
• If you're unsatisfied with your completed request, please wait at least one week before you re-request. If someone follows this rule, don't waste posts by complaining about it.
• Reminder that nobody is entitled to a delivery under any circumstances within these threads. Don't critique others' requests. If you don't like it, don't draw it.
• Stay on topic. This thread has been deleted twice!

>Artists and Artists-to-Be:
• Feel free to drop your tumblrs/websites/commission/etc information, but if you're dropping your commission info, please consider filling a request beforehand instead of just advertising.

Drawfags open for commissions:
>https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Nqc3xPYS7GiM7w4JKapsOutrTYbXTR0i2LjxbltjbpE/edit#gid=0

https://www.quickposes.com/en/gestures/random

name: Anonymous
com:
The basic premise is that humanity used to be a galaxy spanning empire, but some force has destroyed almost every human planet.
There are only nine human planets left now. Technically they're under one empire but realistically none of the planets are united. Each is basically its own isolated culture living under very sub-optimal conditions.
Something now threatens these nine planets.

The players aren't your traditional heros. They're some of the few people with ftl communication, and basically all they can do as a collective is communicate with eachtoher.
The game would be on a discord server and happen asynchronously, because that's almost exactly what the characters would be experiencing. They can only type so so can their players.
Most of the actual challenge is through weird logic puzzles, and negotiations with inhuman npcs.

Basically homestuck meets 40k. But I can't just lead with calling it that.

Can I play as a space bee?', 'time': 1670651634, 'resto': 86922803}, {'no': 86984453, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)00:55:35', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86934125
Bees are winged insects closely related to wasps and ants, known for their roles in pollination and, in the case of the best-known bee species, the western honey bee, for producing honey. Bees are a monophyletic lineage within the superfamily Apoidea. They are presently considered a clade, called Anthophila. There are over 16,000 known species of bees in seven recognized biological families.[1][2] Some species– including honey bees, bumblebees, and stingless bees– live socially in colonies while most species (>90%)– including mason bees, carpenter bees, leafcutter bees, and sweat bees– are solitary.

Bees are found on every continent except Antarctica, in every habitat on the planet that contains insect-pollinated flowering plants. The most common bees in the Northern Hemisphere are the Halictidae, or sweat bees, but they are small and often mistaken for wasps or flies. Bees range in size from tiny stingless bee species, whose workers are less than 2 millimetres (0.08in) long,[3] to Megachile pluto, the largest species of leafcutter bee, whose females can attain a length of 39 millimetres (1.54in).

Bees feed on nectar and pollen, the former primarily as an energy source and the latter primarily for protein and other nutrients. Most pollen is used as food for their larvae. Vertebrate predators of bees include primates and birds such as bee-eaters; insect predators include beewolves and dragonflies.

Human beekeeping or apiculture (meliponiculture for stingless bees) has been practised for millennia, since at least the times of Ancient Egypt and Ancient Greece. Bees have appeared in mythology and folklore, through all phases of art and literature from ancient times to the present day, although primarily focused in the Northern Hemisphere where beekeeping is far more common. In Mesoamerica, the Mayans have practiced large-scale intensive meliponiculture since pre-Columbian times.[3]', 'time': 1670651735, 'resto': 86922803}, {'no': 86985099, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)02:28:27', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86984453

Thread Question: What's the most important thing to you in a system centered around ERP?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86986337, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)06:18:52', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86986332

On to the Scenario books:

This is the real meat of the game. If the core system is the bones, they fall apart without the material included in these. This is also where you find a lot of the creatures and situations that your character runs into. There's two of these, the Kingdoms book and the Fey one and largely the Fey one seems to have more care put into it. Both books feel like there's a lot of copy and paste between the different types of areas and the creatures you can encounter and especially with the way the Kingdoms book was written (the one I read first) I started to wonder why a lot of these weren't just some universal table because they were the same things over and over with very little to differentiate what makes an encounter with one type of antagonist different to any other. And a lot of the resolutions for having sex was either just noting whether it was consensual or not or whether it was a possibility and the number of participants. I'm kind of reminded a bit of the Events system in the d100 Dungeon book World Builder which adds a word of explorable hexes to adventure in. Instead of repeating the same situations on all these tables, having a master list of the types of events would go a long way to collecting and understanding the different things that can happen when they're so similar between tables.', 'time': 1670671132, 'resto': 86965956}, {'no': 86986342, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)06:19:52', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86986337

But the Fey book does a much better job of having events unique to the different places and creatures you run into. There's still a lot of repetition, but at least then I was able to get a glimpse of what the game should look like. The one thing I feel is really missing from the antagonist descriptions (which is sort of HOW they do sex, like what their preferences for situations are) gets mentioned more, but in a roundabout way in the events where you meet other victims in peril.

Another thing that kind of surprised me is that there's a lot of repetition in reprinting a lot of the information between books(pdfs) It actually kind of makes it harder to find the information you want because you have to browse through stuff that's repeated elsewhere and I bet it makes editing these things a pain whenever anything gets updated.', 'time': 1670671192, 'resto': 86965956}, {'no': 86986348, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)06:20:52', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86986342
Overall:

I think Lewd Attack is almost a good game. It has a good core to its system and a lot of the issues I had with it are on the content/editing side. The race and class selection felt a bit limiting too, especially considering how modular they look. It probably wouldn't take much to make it into something that give players a bit more freedom with making their characters not fit into what looks like a weirdly rigid structure.

Since I mentioned it before, here's an excerpt from the d100 Dungeon World Builder book, under events, which pretty relevant to lewd games!
>CAPTURE: The adventurer is grabbed by a handful of thugs. They are trying to tie the adventurer’s hands and feet. The adventurer must struggle to break free by making a number of STRUGGLE,
WRIGGLE, TRICK tests. During the tests you will be generating a Break Free (BF) number. The BF number begins at 5, and if it reaches 0 the adventurer has managed to break free; however, if the BF result reaches 10 the adventurer is captured and restrained. There are 3 types of tests the adventurer may choose from, however the same test may not be performed in succession.
>STRUGGLE – Test: Str -20 [S:-1 BF] [F:+1 BF] (Strong)
>WRIGGLE – Test: Dex -20 [S:-1 BF] [F:+1 BF] (Agility)
>TRICK – Test: Int -20 [S:-1 BF] [F:+1 BF] (Aware)
>If the adventurer manages to break free and they are on a ship, they dive overboard, see SWIM event. Otherwise, they run to safety, but are now being hunted, see HUNTED event. If they are restrained and on a ship, they are sold to slavers, see SLAVERY event. Otherwise, roll the d6. On a result of 1-3 they are sold into slavery, see SLAVERY event, on a result of 4-5 they are taken to a jail to await prosecution, see JAIL event, and on a result of 6 they decide to skip the whole legal route, and take the adventurer to the nearest tree to be hung, see HANGING event.', 'time': 1670671252, 'resto': 86965956}, {'no': 86986529, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)06:56:59', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985214
>Meanwhile in the lewd game I'm in the sub players are the biggest optimizers and sometimes accidentally skip lewd encounters

They had to suggest ways to the GM to get them to surrender in-character more often', 'time': 1670673419, 'resto': 86965956}, {'no': 86986610, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)07:08:46', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86986529
I had a fellow player apologize to me once because he had his character be overly competent and get us both out of some peril that I had already lost my rolls on so I am right there with you!
In general it's not a bad idea to communicate with your GM the ways you want to lose or things that you're looking forward to when it comes to lewd games. As much as it'd be great to have a GM that always correctly guesses what your fetish needs and wants are before even you know, the truth of the matter is that no one is a mind reader and people often approach the same fetish from different angles. Communication is key in any kind of relationship and it's so very important in ERP games.', 'time': 1670674126, 'resto': 86965956}]

You think this is a dungeon crawler?', 'time': 1670660232, 'resto': 86985143}, {'no': 86985546, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)03:47:36', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'More or less like >>86985285, but also
>one piece of important information to be revealed
Depending on what the main arc is at the moment this could be about a individual PC, one of the main NPC groups of the game, or the overall world. I like to do flow charts of how the session could potentially flow, even if it's a vague "PCs encounter MONSTER in AREA > players deal with it in some way > PCs discover what was hidden in the area now the monster is not a problem" with a fork for what happens if they walk away. when the session finishes I look back on how the session fits the flow chart and makes notes on the things they did or did not do shape next week.

Keep it simple. Dot point it. Go back and expand later if needed, if the players take interest in a thing. Build what they enjoy and look at, not just what *you* want to run.', 'time': 1670662056, 'resto': 86985143}, {'no': 86985924, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)05:00:34', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985143

name: Anonymous
com: In this thread, we will talk about dwarves. Starter Topic: The Underway or Underway-adjacent structures. Is it feasible for dwarves to carve massive tunnels between their holds like a highway network? Seems like a popular trope but I wonder how long such a massive works project would take.
last_replies:
[{'no': 86984538, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:07:49', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86984511
Elves are boring as fuck and need 500 different flavors to give the veneer of intrigue. Dwarves nailed it on the first go, no need to mess with perfection.', 'filename': 'dwarf_king_and_some_beer_by_artdeepmind_dbcmp22', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 2500, 'h': 1895, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 94, 'tim': 1670652469931105, 'time': 1670652469, 'md5': 'njharDo1wJtxg8VNY9rPUA==', 'fsize': 3928823, 'resto': 86963878}, {'no': 86985702, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)04:19:26', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86974424
To me, Cleric Dwarves are always the big question. I feel like the Dwarven religion is always a good candidate for something less common that what the Humans have. Humans may have a wide, encompassing Pantheon with a central Christian-like figure, but the Dwarves give us a chance for a Civilized race to firmly believe in something strange. Ancestral worship, Viking aesthetics, Maybe they come from the earth and don't have a Soul or an afterlife, Maybe they Spout Fire and Earth Elementalism.
I'm not particularly keen on Dwarven Runesmiths. I can appreicate each race giving a whiff of magic into their weapons to make it special, Halfling Slings seem to bend around corners hunting small game and Elven armorers are famous for their Glass Armor, hard as steel. I like the idea of an isolated perfectionist, dwarven Hephaestus the party has to find. But no one can really agree what Rune smithing means for an adventurer. In normal play are they more Smith, more Mage, or more Fighter? Can a Peasant, Early Game, or Mid Level Fighter pick up a Rune smith weapon and be just as effective? Runesmiths feel more like a supplier to heroes than a combat style. I kinda prefer Runes more for a tribal race of tattoo artists that constantly need to reapply their spell charges.', 'time': 1670663966, 'resto': 86963878}, {'no': 86985711, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)04:21:02', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985702
Despite their disagreements, Dwarves more keenly take on the Elven originated Academic Mage tradition. The Dwarves have a Grand Library central of Information, and all Holds have their own proud collection of Clan History, Bestiaries, practical knowledge, and reports of delving too deep that need upkeep. Librarians and Bureucrats eschew wands, newt eyes, and most weapons for circlets, bracelts, hooded robes, and hand motions, maybe a shortsword letter opener or a medium sized hammer for stamping letters.
Gnomes are more of a philosophy than a race, while Dwarves take pride in the Elements of Fire and Earth. They need all the elements for society to function; Air, Water, and Nature. Gnomish Dwarves are Hippies known for wearing witch hats, beanies, wizards and phrygian caps, who moved away from the busy, judgemental life of society to live in nature. Maybe they cut wood in the woods and live with their spouse in a giant mushroom or with six of their brothers running an ecologically responsible mineshaft. Conservative taste makes them often targets of backhanded and private insults, but like a Midwest religious family seeing their kid go to Africa for missionary work, religious Dwarves will pay Gnomes grateful lip service while never wishing to do it themselves. Gnomes follow the Hedge-wise traditions of potion-making, nature magic, whacking people with a staff.', 'filename': 'Phrygian cap', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 4928, 'h': 3264, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 82, 'tim': 1670664062083883, 'time': 1670664062, 'md5': 'QEmh3XNtnoxxMrDze7ze7A==', 'fsize': 7126322, 'resto': 86963878}, {'no': 86985910, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)04:58:09', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86981366
It's also somewhat comical for a fantasy kitchen sink campaign, where all the Dwarf players have racially aligned Orcish or Elven nemeses but the City the game takes place in is Multicultural and has to factor in personal racial tension. You need a lawyer to understand the circumstances two nemeses are allowed to kill each other.
You can have a group of 4 dwarves who are enemies with an Elf and a pixie working together, who are forced to join forces with an Orc and goblin who hate the your other two Dwarves. In the middle of it is a wanted, desperate, pathetic human noble who bought the rival team as security and he has to keep watching them fuck off to fight their personal vendetta's.

>>86981963
You're still thinking a bit too gamey. it's roleplay not a stat block. Look into Warhammer Fantasy. A Stone Miner, a Sailor, a House Servant, a Political Agitator, and a Tradesmen are separate Careers and a perfectly reasonable party.', 'time': 1670666289, 'resto': 86963878}, {'no': 86986583, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)07:04:54', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86982268
He's pretty cool, but I can't help but notice how absolutely massive his forehead is', 'time': 1670673894, 'resto': 86963878}]

[{'no': 86985538, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)03:45:40', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Hypothetical question. I'm an illusionist and cast Project Image, making a shadow copy of myself I can see/cast through. I cast iInvisibility on it so it's now an invisible illusion. I walk it past a creature with true sight. Does the creature A) see things as they really are, that nothing is there even though that nothing is about fireball it, or B) see through the invisibility to see the illusion(that it also see through) and reacts against it?', 'time': 1670661940, 'resto': 86969440}, {'no': 86985600, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)03:58:48', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985538
B. True Seeing allows you to see through illusions, but it doesn't blind you to them. They would see the Image and know it was false, but be able to react to it. Also note that once the Image casts fireball it would become visible either way as it's attacking a foe.

Also, I'm not 100% sure that the Image qualifies as 'a creature or object' for Invisibility. The text "The projected image can’t cast any spells on itself except for illusion spells" implies that it can cast illusions on itself, but I'm not sure if Invisibility in particular is kosher.', 'time': 1670662728, 'resto': 86969440}, {'no': 86985636, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)04:07:02', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985512
I have been doing wikipedia history dives to adapt to minor adventure ideas and his big ol' speech stuck in my head. Wasn't really used, though. What I'm working out is based on the archaeological explorations of the pyramids during the Ramessid dynasty.', 'time': 1670663222, 'resto': 86969440}, {'no': 86985876, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)04:50:24', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985600
>'a creature or object'
an illusion is not a creature or an object, so I'd say no', 'time': 1670665824, 'resto': 86969440}, {'no': 86986565, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)07:02:38', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985876
To slightly complicate things, Project Image is a Shadow spell, which does create a quasi-real intangible duplicate of the caster. It could very well be a thing.', 'time': 1670673758, 'resto': 86969440}]

name: Anonymous
com:
Does anyone have experience with using A.I. Generated art in tabletop rpgs?

Most of the attention nowadays is on 2d art, but I think the best use for this technology is in making text. It’s a quick way to generate lots of unexpected and original locations, descriptions, items, characters, etc.

But the 2d art could be good for generating quick references for characters and stuff too.

Anyways: ideas or thoughts on this stuff?

name: Anonymous
com:
Is creating an alternate timeline of an estabilished setting for a campaign the laziest form of worldbuilding?
One could simply put the alterations done into an original world but decides to not do so. For name recognition or by believing he can do a better job than the author.
I remember looking for a Deathwatch game in rolld20 years ago and one of the open campaigns for newcomers summary was some alternate Imperium where the Emperor is ressurrected by an all powerful entity only known as the Empress who becomes his consort and that stuck with me.
Alternates to our own realities are exempt of this judgement because I really like the ones where the ERE still exist.

name: Anonymous
com:
Vermin of valour edition
Previous thread: >>86941998

>What is /awg/?
A thread to talk about minis and games which fall between the cracks, or peoples' homebrew wargames. The >>>/tg/hwg thread doesn't entertain fantasy (for good reason) and the other threads are locked to more specific games.
This thread isn't tied to a game, a publisher, or a genre, let's just talk about fun wargames. Any scale, any genre, any company, any miniatures. Skirmishers welcome. Rules designers welcome.

>Examples of games that qualify
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_miniature_wargames
OnePageRules, Warzone, Mighty Armies, Warmachine & Hordes, Dragon Rampant, Oathmark, Mortal Gods, Kings of War, Firefight, Deadzone, Warpath, Frost/Stargrave, Hordes of the Things, Gaslands, Conquest, Songs of Blades and Heroes, Dark Age, Beyond the Gates of Antares, Malifaux, and anything else that doesn't necessarily have a dedicated thread.

>Places to get minis
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1D2DbNJ2mYAUxh5P9Pq9NZqS5tXHGn0i2JhZchEwbA2I/edit
https://www.dakkadakka.com/dakkaforum/posts/list/373197.page
Updates to the minis list are welcome.

>The Novice Troves
https://pastebin.com/MjtsC8AX
https://mega.nz/#F!zSYW0I4a!vXh8-UPi_tWXpJES_-p4zg
These troves are currently full, and meant to serve as a sampler of available systems. Check out the sharethread for more up-to-date troves

>Thread Theme
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XjvBP7JzbFM

What are you working on at the moment?

Any chance we'll ever see a Sandact spin on Abyssal charms? How would you go about it, if that were the case?', 'time': 1670667444, 'resto': 86975815}, {'no': 86986192, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)05:54:59', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86983859
>2nd edition's take on it doesn't deserve to be described in more generous terms than I described it.

I have no problems with 2Es take. Lunar-Taming Leash (I think that's what it was called) was in Dreams of the First Age. We know non-Sidereal charmsets are malleable. So it's entirely on-brand for First Age Solars to take this soulmate bond, and turn into some sort of domination thing.

Doesn't mean the PCs have to, or even are encouraged to. In 2E, everything was described in terms of stats. So these charms that exist to show the depths of the depravity of FA Solars are also available for your players to take. And, to be honest, I like it that way. The Solar game is about trying to toe the line between saviour and abomination. You need to have charms that tempt you to fall, or you lose that whole dynamic.', 'time': 1670669699, 'resto': 86975815}, {'no': 86986264, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)06:05:55', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86986192

Ah, my bad. Still it's introduced with the line "This Charm is the result of Solar paranoia in

name: Anonymous
com:
Welcome to the Old School Renaissance General, the thread dedicated to TSR-era D&D, derived systems, and compatible content.

Broadly, OSR games encourage a tonal and mechanical fidelity to Dungeons & Dragons as played in the game's first decade—less emphasis on linear adventures and overarching meta-plots and a greater emphasis on player agency.

If you are new to the OSR, welcome! Ask us whatever you're curious about: we'll be happy to help you get started.

>Resources, Blogs, etc:
http://pastebin.com/9fzM6128

>Need a starter dungeon? Here's a curated collection:
https://archive.4plebs.org/tg/thread/86342023/#q86358321

>Previous Thread:
>>86915602

Have you ran or played in the City State of the Invincible Overlord? Tell us about the game (or maybe why you decided to give it a pass).

More barter trade, small-to-moderate amounts of wealth stored in long-lasting goods (fine cloth, tools and utensils, non-perishable foodstuffs, etc.) rather than currencry.

>>86984327
This may seem like I'm Skerpleing, but I've been thinking about hex maps lately too. Aside from the obvious "islands and mountains follow fault lines" and "rivers flow downhill and usually come together rather than split apart" - link related is thinking about introducing challenges to hex maps in addition to verisimilitude, by design attempting to translate some of the same elements of dungeon mapping and exploration into wilderness adventures.

Additionally, there is an old podcast, Hex Talk, which you could listen through. There are only half a dozen episodes or so - but it's got some insights from a handful of friends who have been running hex adventures for a long time.

com:
previous thread: >>86804700

<<<<<<<< READ THE PDF BEFORE ASKING WHERE TO START

GURPS is a modular, adaptable system, capable of running a wide range of characters, settings, and play styles with level of detail varying from lightweight to completely autistic.
Optional rules allow you to emulate different genres with a single system, even switching genres within a single game.

A nearly complete archive of GURPS books can be found by those who pay attention to file extensions.
Never post direct links to the archive anywhere.

If you're wondering where to start:
The Basic Set covers everything, including a lot of optional rules you probably won't use.
A genre guide can be found in the archive, under Unofficial > GURPSgen. It tells you what extra books and articles you may find useful for many common genres.
How To be a GURPS GM is a good read even for players.
GCS (gurpscharactersheet.com) is an excellent character builder software with page references to all the books and the option to export to both Foundry and Fantasy Grounds.

TQ: Will AI art really save GURPS artwork problem?

>okcupid', 'time': 1670661241, 'resto': 86963915}, {'no': 86986389, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)06:27:47', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86976488
Following on this we had also a child villain in the next art. In summary, she was a child scientist (a child genius esentially) specialized in robotics and robotizing people (like Eggman from sonic). Esentially, she was groomed by the BBEG intro a mad scientis after she suffered some serious trauma (her brother died and her best friend got seriously ill and fell intro a coma) and started experimenting with robotics (getting shunned by it, and the BBEG took advantage of it to get a robot army designed by her). She did pretty fucked up stuff such as experimenting with people, creating a LOT of weapons (such as mountain sized and skyscrapper sized mechs that the BBEG is currently using) and robotized the commatose friend into one of her generals (while suppresing her mind so she was esentially a slave) that we rescated and freed from the control, among other stuff.

Again, we managed to put her to our side... via forcing her to see her friend's memories (and the pain she endured during her time as a general) and being hit in the face with a metaphorical brick with that (and partially literaly because that was after a fight with her). Currently she is interested in helping us and trying to fix the damage she did, but the last part will take a LONG time. One could argue that she didn't deserve to live, but my character believes in redemption and the good in people's heart, so when he can, he tries to make evildoers leave that behind, fix the damage they did and become better persons afterward, so she gets a second chance (under surveillance like the kaiju).', 'time': 1670671667, 'resto': 86963915}]

Europe has priests, angels (Biblically accurate), demons (from the Lesser Key of Solomon), faeries (not Tinkerbell), werewolves, and vampires. But Japan has shrine maidens, Amaterasu, kami, youkai, kitsune, tanuki, oni, tsukumogami, etc. etc. etc.

Who will the players play?

Alessandro Valignano, 1584:
"[The Japanese] excel not only all the other Oriental peoples, they surpass the Europeans as well."

António Bocarro, 1635:
"The strength and courage of the Japanese in arms is such that there is no nation whatsoever which would dare to invade Japan; likewise their self-confidence and pride is greater than that of any other people yet discovered, wherefore wheresoever they go they are universally esteemed for their courage, and have proved it in deeds."

"Relations of Mme de St Troppez", October 1615, Bibliothèque Inguimbertine, Carpentras:
"They never touch food with their fingers, but instead use two small sticks that they hold with three fingers."
"They blow their noses in soft silky papers the size of a hand, which they never use twice, so that they throw them on the ground after usage, and they were delighted to see our people around them precipitate themselves to pick them up."

After some trial and error we banned some cards as Deck Masters (specifically floodgates, that was literally the first thing that went even before we played, negates, and anything immune to destruction soon after) and did a simple "if used as material or tribute the new card is your deck master (including opponent Kaiju effects)". Activated effects can activate as long as the conditions are met. We also added that cards that require cards on the field (say Thousand knives for Dark Magician or Meisei, which is the only floodgates allowed because you're playing Meisei) count the deck master as being on the field, but any permanent changes (LADD ATK drop, if he was allowed, counters, or the like) don't apply. We use the standard ban TCG list.
I know most people consider it a bad format but it's really fun with not a lot of changes. It allows for a wider variety of strategies. com:
The main gimmick of Humans in my D 'n' D game is that they're the only guys smart, intelligent, and cunning enough to eat bugs instead of meat.

Dwarfs in Dwarfia (the country where all the Dwarfs are) love sushi and pepperoni pizza.

Elfs in Elfia (the country where all the Elfs are) love quintuple cheeseburgers and BBQ fried chicken.

But it's only in Humania (the country where all the Humans are) where you can eat worm tacos and candied locusts.

This is how Humans get +2 CON. Just like in real life, the one thing Humans excel at beyond everyone else is endurance hunting and endurance running.

What guys are the eater of bugs in your D 'n' D game?

>game has been trapped in a stagnant loop of "draw the out" formats and the meatiest gameplay interactions can only be found at the tipping end of competitive archetypes, and most of them are mirror matches
>official side formats have only recently emerged, and are strictly niche/undersupported/unpopular in comparison to the modern metagame meaning edison/goat is reserved for a very tiny part of the community
>consistent power creep means even casual matches with petdecks are played with dubious levels of balance, a petdeck from a year ago has a good chance of getting thrashed by one from today, or even vice versa
I enjoy the game as much as I enjoy every other card game I play, and I play basically everything but it's pretty baffling to me that the game is still a monolith today even if a good chunk of that is sunk cost/people who never touch the competitive side.
>>86971879
>FaB is gaining because Wizards and Konami are dying
We're more or less in a card game renaissance right now, say what you will about either company but you're always going to see the decline of 20+ year veterans more than their inclines, no excuse for Magic though', 'filename': '__tearlaments_scheiren_and_tearlaments_kitkallos_yu_gi_oh_drawn_by_hsin__4a8ef4e4acdebc360515ad6ee24a329b', 'ext': '.png', 'w': 1165, 'h': 1600, 'tn_w': 91, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670669785436431, 'time': 1670669785, 'md5': 'DvuEDSe5x9SqTleGYk2AOQ==', 'fsize': 2744286, 'resto': 86907061}, {'no': 86986221, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)05:59:35', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985947
They used palette swaps for these because they were made in the age of the dinosaurs where barely any consideration was thrown into attaching cards to art past the anime staples. name: Anonymous
com:
Hey there, everyone; how's it going? I've been working on a game called COGS over the past couple of years (a small number of people may even already know of it from a few threads I've posted it in). Yesterday, I launched a Kickstarter for it at https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/scribblegs/cogs-expanded-edition to fund a physical release filled with artwork and more supplemental material. It's got a small goal compared to some projects I've seen for FUCKING 5E SUPPLEMENTS, and a good chunk of the funding will probably go toward shipping and printing costs before anything else. However, I would appreciate any help that my fellow fa/tg/uys can provide by backing or spreading the word to people they feel might be interested.

>fuck your shill thread, faggot
Now I've been on /tg/ for a couple of years now; I perfectly get being mad about a shill thread and won't really object if I get called a faggot for it. However, I want to make clear that I would personally rather shill on 4chan and get called a fag than ever set foot on the unholy trash fire known as reddit.

>So where's the game then, gayboy?
I'm not a psychopath, don't worry. There is a free (or, well, PWYW at the moment) version of the game available on both DTRPG and itch.io at https://www.drivethrurpg.com/product/382321/COGS--Generic-Oneshot-Generala-System and https://scribblegs.itch.io/cogs, respectively. Unfortunately, the text is still choppy at times since I'm a single amateur writer with no editor. However, the plan for the free versions, whether the Kickstarter succeeds or fails, is to update them to match the expanded edition and make them entirely free (not PWYW). They would become the "basic" game version, with no artwork and little supplemental content (like character creation tips, example content, or establishing expected power levels). However, it would still feature what rules and extra content they already have (which is already enough to play a game).

1/2

[{'no': 86977848, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)11:17:22', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86973700
DevAnon, can you give me a quick example of play? Specifically, what would commonly prompt a roll, what are the mechanics of the roll, and what are the general outcomes for rolls?', 'time': 1670602642, 'resto': 86955816}, {'no': 86980270, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)16:12:11', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86977848
I mean the system is made to be what i felt the essentials of a game were (action resolution, ways to make things challenging without just raising the TN, actual abilities outside of basic rolls) so the gameplay is pretty standard fare.

You make a roll to do anything that requires any level of skill or effort, like muscling through things, parkour, investigating something, resisting the effects of drugs or mind control, soothing or inciting the rage in a crowd. No matter the action, you roll a hand of poker dice (5d6). Theres 8 hand types worth between 0 and 5 points (and most are straightforward, like 1 pair being worth 1 point or 5 of a kind being worth 5). If you describe your action or use a helpful trait or item you can get up to 3 boons, each boon letting you reroll any number of dice one time

If its a normal action, you roll against a target number between 1 and 5; if it's a contested action you roll against the opponent. It's binary succeed-fail (never cared much for crits), though examples are given for how to make the outcome better for scoring above the TN and damage is equal to the difference in contested rolls', 'time': 1670620331, 'resto': 86955816}, {'no': 86981565, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)18:56:14', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Bump because I read through one of your PDFs a few months ago and it seemed neat, although not really my style.', 'time': 1670630174, 'resto': 86955816}, {'no': 86984689, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:26:34', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86955816

It always seemed weird we had a Kaita for Toa and a Nui for Turaga and Matoran', 'time': 1670651372, 'resto': 86918206}, {'no': 86985052, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)02:21:17', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'I'm putting a bionicle-inspired Mata-Nui adventure into my pathfinder campaign. Only one of my players has any actual knowledge of bionicle so it should be a fun time. Tribes of automatons, construct monsters around the island, party has to travel between the lost island shrines to complete trials pertaining to the elements to reactivate the main central shrine. Each dungeon begins with a meeting with a robot guide (the same each time) that slowly regains more and more function and coherency as more temples are completed. The robot guide is the still living part of the setting's god of life that has been missing for a few generations now.

What do you think are some good bionicle-esque encounters I could give my players while they explore the island and visit the villages? Should I just adapt the Mata-Nui online game for them to play through?', 'filename': 'Screenshot_20221210_021204', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 859, 'h': 816, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 118, 'tim': 1670656877410114, 'time': 1670656877, 'md5': 'tunHdtzGgVwe/dEjEftzJg==', 'fsize': 367258, 'resto': 86918206}, {'no': 86986147, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)05:47:59', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86984368
Arguably one of the most mishandled concepts with painful amounts of unused potential. It's an established ability that could have interesting uses but Greg kept ignoring it after the toy designers stopped making fusion models. Except when he added the Matoran Nui in one of the 2004 books, even though that wasn't based on the toys.
The original two Kaita sorta fell victim to the retconning of the early lore and the cancelled 2001 video game. According to the game and other promos, the Kaita were unique fusions that could only exist when the Toa gathered the Makoki stones to activate the underground Kaita chamber, which was technically inside Mata Nui's head. It wasn't an ability the Toa could do at any time. But post-2001, Kaita combos had no such limitations anymore, the Toa, the Bohrok, the Kal, the Rahkshi could all do it at any time without the need of special chambers or artifacts. The removal of this limitation made it all the more stupid that Kaita just got ignored in later canon.
And Greg said Toa Nui straight up can't exist, so what was the point of having them?', 'time': 1670669279, 'resto': 86918206}]

In a world of fantasy, there could also be giant plants for gigantic herbivore to eat. You can also incorporate magic to their diet where they absorb the mana in the air or the plants they eat to sustein themselves. Also the added bonus of making the prey able to use magic. Try to hunt a skywhale? It summons a hurricane to hurl your ass.', 'time': 1670639151, 'resto': 86966367}, {'no': 86983681, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)22:58:31', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86972175
A lot of predators are smaller than the things they hunt. Wolves are smaller than elks, hawks and falcons are often smaller than chickens, leopards and tigers are smaller than the ungulates they eat, etc. Size is not a significant hunting advantage. Two things
One: Has someone made a homebrew conversion for Delta Green to essentially be that the players are part of an XCOM squad, going on missions around the world to slow down and eventually stop an alien invasion?
Two (not as important): Has people homebrewed in fantasy player races?', 'time': 1670648202, 'resto': 86934469}, {'no': 86984353, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)00:38:53', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86938453

That question goes to the heart of the tone of whatever game you want, so you need to answer it yourself. Whatever you think the 'real' answer is, you need to pick the one here that best defines the parameters of the game you want, because it will be almost as important as the mechanics themselves.

Is the supernatural very rare, and engaging with it requires a form of insanity to begin with? You have an Unknown Armies situation, where the supernatural is inherently self-limiting, the secret keeps itself, and there's always a reason to explain it away. If you have rare supernatural but going insane is a consequence of experiencing it rather than a precondition TO experiencing it, you end up with Call of Chthulu.

If the supernatural is rare but not unheard of ,and has a mild risk of being contagious, you end up with a Delta Green situation, where a few people know about it and control it, but you need to actively limit the spread of information because that is dangerous. The government can be involved but maybe you don't want them involved. If it's about as rare but the knowledge of the supernatural isn't inherently destructive, you end up with a Hellboy/BPRD situation, where probably is a few governmental/NGO forces to respond to these events since they can be documented and proven, but because they are rare and dangerous everyone prefers not to really make them public. And then if you ever really, truly fuck up one of these things, you end up like a later BPRD situation, where the quiet supernatural has gone extremely loud, it is probably the Apocalypse, but it is going to be decades long and you still have the means to fight it even if you can't comprehend winning.

All very different tones, just from how common and knowable the supernatural element is.', 'time': 1670650733, 'resto': 86934469}, {'no': 86985997, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)05:16:36', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86983363
Can you elaborate on said patreon errata? I'm not married to the baseline DG system, I just deeply dislike the 7e one and would like something quicker.', 'time': 1670667396, 'resto': 86934469}]

com:
Fundamental Forces Edition

Welcome to /wbg/, the official thread for the discussion of in-progress settings for traditional games.

Here is where you go to present and develop the details of your worlds such as lore, factions, magic and ecosystems. You can also post maps for your settings, as well as any relevant art (either created by you or used as inspiration for your work). Please remember that dialogue is what keeps the thread alive, not asking questions to OP every third hour.

Last Thread: >>86797171

Resources for Newfags: https://sites.google.com/view/wbgeneral/
Worldbuilding links: https://pastebin.com/JNnj79S5
https://cryptpad.fr/pad/#/2/pad/view/Eo+fK41FKVR7xDpbNO0a0N4k0YYxrmyrhX3VxnM14Ew/
Fantasy map generator: https://watabou.itch.io/medieval-fantasy-city-generator

Thread Questions:

>What are the fundamental underlying forces of your setting? Did you go with picture related or something else?
>Did you add or change any of the forces?
>Are there any technologies, magic, or other kinds of powers able to manipulate these forces in your setting? If so, how do they work?
>How do you handle elements? Do you prefer the classical elements, chemical elements, or a mix of both?
>Finally, if there are any entities that embody these forces or elements? If so, what are they like?

name: Anonymous
com:
Has anyone done it?
What kind of wonders have your adventurers found there?
What subquests would you suggest?
I've always loved the idea of exploring a brand new continent with alien landscapes and creatures, but I'm not sure how to handle the actual exploration in an interesting way.
How to make the players genuinely curious about the land?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86981388, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)18:32:48', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86981354
>But this is fantasy. Everywhere is mostly-similar-but-with-unexpected-differences.
Not necessarily, a new continent can be as alien as you want.
Most alien worlds also fit your description, since it's hard to come up with something that doesn't work with our logic, so all we do is alter our common sense and call it alien.', 'time': 1670628768, 'resto': 86980827}, {'no': 86981566, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)18:56:21', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86981388

What I mean is that an alien planet in fantasy can still have leafy trees and grassy fields and birds and deer (or deer-cousins), even if the species aren't exactly the same, which is the same thing I would expect from another continent in a scifi setting.

Conversely, sure, a fantasy setting can have a rabbit hole that leads to a floating fungus carpet in a forest of floating fungus carpets with no visible ground. It can be more alien than an alien world. But "alien" in this context should mean it's somehow divided from the local nature-gods, or from whatever it is that causes so much of the multiverse with intelligent humanoids and earth-like life.', 'time': 1670630181, 'resto': 86980827}, {'no': 86982295, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)20:24:35', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86980827
>Has anyone done it?
Someone has, at least six times. Robots another dozen or so, but with less adventure and no flora or fauna.

>How to make the players genuinely curious about the land?
Evidence of stuff (beasts, people, resources, landforms, landmarks, cyclopean cities) before they encounter it, which can't easily be misattributed to stuff they have encountered. Rumors before evidence. Pair plothooks with a rumor and an evidence of unrelated things. Don't make disease impossible for an expedition to endure.', 'time': 1670635475, 'resto': 86980827}, {'no': 86984640, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:20:44', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86980827
It's not really possible since my world is kind of globalised and every continent is well-established.', 'time': 1670653244, 'resto': 86980827}, {'no': 86985945, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)05:04:00', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Bump.', 'time': 1670666640, 'resto': 86980827}]

name: Notepad Anon
com:
It's a Holy Jolly December, can we ever be redeemed? Welcome to the December thread of homebrew discussion on /tg/. This is part of my effort to get people discussing classic homebrew discussion and assist the board in general when it comes to their game design endeavors.

>Who is this namefaggot?
I'm just a dude who writes games and likes the homebrew discussions on /tg/. I frequent a few threads, but I'm just here to facilitate discussion. I was [BusinessMaxxing] in the UK last month, I'm back and scored some fackin' goals.

>Why should I homebrew?
/tg/ products are fairly unique in that it's actually pretty simple to make them these days, with a plethora of products to assist in making and playtesting your game. Making your own games helps understand why games are made the way they are, as well as being fun to do.

>What you should post
Ideas for games, games you're currently making, updates to your own games in broad strokes, and any homebrewing for existing products that don't get much attention. Discussion about the above is welcome. Post good, be good, and look over others products, they care if someone looks more than anything.

>Oh No! The Thread is Over!
Have no fear, the thread will resume at the first of every month. If you want to make another during the month, go for it. I can't, and won't, stop you. If you want to make a thread on your own game, go for it!
One suggestion: Don't add General to the name. Mid-Month Threads are "relatively" common.

>Resources for the aspiring developer
>https://anydice.com/ (A fantastic resource for checking probabilities)
>https://miro.com/ (A online whiteboard with tools to help organize yourself)
>https://www.notion.so/ (Similar to the above, but in a bit cleaner format for those who work in larger teams)
>https://rolz.org/ (Impromptu playtesting at its finest)
>https://www.youtube.com/user/georgephillies/playlists (Game Design Lectures)

i also really want to increase the amount of maneuvers, like, the ideal would be completely doubling them before addint any more magic to the game', 'filename': 'EuROgxIUYAY68ae', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 1152, 'h': 2048, 'tn_w': 70, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670657300139086, 'time': 1670657300, 'md5': 'DUS5ZehUUFoPxbg/1ZnXbA==', 'fsize': 359172, 'resto': 86896333}, {'no': 86985210, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)02:44:51', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'Im thinking about using luck as HP, with characters expending a luck point when they get "hit" to narrowly evade harm. Luck may be restored by being blessed by a priest. However, when you run out of luck points you will have to save vs death every time you get hit. If you succeed, then you only receive an injury rather than suffering instant death. Even if you succeed against all of your death saves, you will still die if you receive too many injuries.

With that in mind, Im unsure how to implement armor. Attackers hit by rolling under their skill level, so rolling against an armor score is out and I dont think it makes sense for armor to come into the equation before your luck anyway. I figure the armor could reduce the chance of suffering instant death and that alone is pretty strong but is that reason enough to motivate a player to deck themselves out?', 'time': 1670658291, 'resto': 86896333}, {'no': 86985680, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)04:14:49', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86896333
My favourite thread of the month.
Making a cape-system and I'm thinking of using a "Success" result system. 3+stat d6's is the initial idea. Each dice result that's 4+ is a "Score", that word being used to separate it from regular "You succeed with 4 successes". For each score above the Target Number you get to add an embellishment. "You succeed, and..." you get to fill in the blank with a minor addition.
The doomsday remote isn't just knocked out of Dr. Horrible's hand, it's flung into the volcano, or it slides over to an you or an ally, shit like that. It'll probably work both ways, with the GM deciding the "and..." bit for the NPCs.
Another thing I was going to steal was the "GYRO" scene tracker from Sentinel Comics. Basically, as the fight goes on, tension mounts and higher "tier" abilities are unlocked.
What I'm asking, in addition if that resolution system is shit, is how should powers be added? Effects like Mutants & Masterminds? Or actual powers like Prowlers & Paragons.', 'filename': 'hero1', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 450, 'h': 300, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 83, 'tim': 1670663689067435, 'time': 1670663689, 'md5': 'NrBNiEOf23ON/c/+SFFPHA==', 'fsize': 25934, 'resto': 86896333}]

>Is life in the underhive really THAT bad?
How far down do you mean? Consider how tall hive structures are and just how deep the foundations might go. Really, the answer is going to vary depending on the hive. Bad ones might be totally anarchic beyond a certain level, with the locals living off of a Dwarf Fortress style ecosystem and not even knowing who the Emperor is or speaking the same language as those who live above. If the Hive is based on mining or something, though, then the deep areas might be important and fairly normal. You might also find bastions of order deep down even in the worst places - isolated Mechanicus shrines that maintain the ancient machinery of the Hive's most powerful generatoria or a cult of Ministorum monks who tend the forgotten cathedrals constructed during initial colonization.', 'time': 1670640442, 'resto': 86912949}, {'no': 86983134, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:57:39', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86982988

That sounds exhausting, confusing, and extremely "extra". I will CONCEDE, however, that I am guilty of something *like* that with how I personally use the term "Humanoid".
I use Humanoid as more of a term ascribed to mortal species that are Human-like in their psychology. It's more of an anthropological term: a Humanoid possess free-will, uses technology, develops arts & crafts, participates in religion, etc.. Humanoids do Human-like things. I had to make this distinction for two reasons: 1. Centaurs are Humanoid in behavior, but not physiology. 2. There's intelligent/sapient species that don't quite make it over the threshold. They're more like a Homoerectus: not a Human, not quite a Cromagnon, but you couldn't consider them a mere beast anymore.

Luckily this is all just an autistic rant.
None of my players have needed this national geographic talk they get the distinction.', 'filename': 'Anime_Confused', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 314, 'h': 291, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 115, 'tim': 1670656877192074, 'time': 1670656877, 'md5': 'gej/1cLIwEIS5tuRVMOoSw==', 'fsize': 15924, 'resto': 86984836}, {'no': 86985581, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)03:55:05', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86985051

I like building my character as I play rather than deciding them from the start.
Having all characters the same as baseline then carving a niche as the campaign progress could sound appealing to people who don't normally play.', 'time': 1670655030, 'resto': 86966300}, {'no': 86984939, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)02:04:41', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86984847
Great mechanical premise, everyone starts the same then grows throughout the game. Is their growth radical and physically changing, or simple learning and collection of experiences? Should your character naturally grow into actions they perform during the game, or by player fiat building them towards a specific role? Should the baseline be something predetermined by the game, or something created cooperatively by the players?
What kind of backdrop should we base the game in? If the players are all mechanically identical from the beginning, then they could operate as clones of the same character, AI constructs that can modify their frames, biomechanical monsters that grow as they devour, etc, for a more scifi bent. Alternatively, things like golems, bound magical or mythological creatures, or simply fresh soldiers for a more fantastical bent.', 'filename': 'Armour and Cloth', 'ext': '.png', 'w': 589, 'h': 926, 'tn_w': 79, 'tn_h': 124, 'tim': 1670655881106902, 'time': 1670655881, 'md5': 'Fvv0r8IWmJp4vUg+ukVJxQ==', 'fsize': 1267055, 'resto': 86966300}, {'no': 86985075, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)02:24:42', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86966300
They used to be more fun before bumpfag or the bot or whoever the fuck keeps posting those retarded questions came along and youtube parasites started displaying threads for the viewing pleasure of an untold number of redditors.', 'time': 1670657082, 'resto': 86966300}, {'no': 86985571, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)03:53:47', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86984939
Players develop their characters by scavenging new civilizations.
Learning their arts and taking their crafts.
Both integrated into their bodies to create a more specialized form.
This basically combines receiving magical items with leveling up.
Or making cyberware an upgrade rather than a trade off.

It has the fun effect of slowly transforming your character the more you integrate better tools in your repertoire.
So seeing some dude with long arms, bulky back servos, and a high grade lens eye will tell you he's a sniper archer.
Every build seems fresh when even though you know the destination, you don't know how to get there.
You want to be a tanky hammersman? Cool.
You have no idea how an amphibious kingdoms of psychic frogs is going to get you there, but you'll probably find something that can help.

The system inclines all sorts of players to engage with it.
Want an adventure? Go scavenge.
Want to get stronger? Go scavenge.
Want to meet new people? Go scavenge.
Improvement is non-linear. Meaning a veteran combat player could be as fresh as a newcomer in a social campaign.
This gives each character a longer half life than average. Lets them gather more stories before retiring/dying.

I think this leans more into freeform, which may pose some problems.
Most of the mechanic's weight will fall onto the GM on top of developing the world and a coherent campaign.
There's also the option of trusting the player to develop their own upgrades.
However, doing so requires responsibility and temperance.
Moreover, I've heard the majority of players don't actually like freeform systems.
They prefer hard mechanics (but not too hard) so they can just act out a build.

One possible solution is to make XP a point buy.
Harder adventures gives more XP. Easier lesser.
The level up page just provides mechanics that can be mixed and match into 1 "tool."
The aesthetics of the tool depends on the player and what world they've just scavenged.

Any more ideas, anons?', 'filename': '32091', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 750, 'h': 598, 'tn_w': 125, 'tn_h': 99, 'tim': 1670662427272471, 'time': 1670662427, 'md5': 'UXgNWGwLIcgJ/L3iNbKW5w==', 'fsize': 75808, 'resto': 86966300}]

name: Chronicler
com:
Writing General: 'Fanfiction' edition.

Welcome to /wg/, the thread for all /tg/ related writing. Whether you're plotting your campaign, trying to come up with a character backstory, or just trying to write some setting fluff, this is the place to post it. You don't even have a campaign, just an idea you want to develop? You're welcome here. While the rest of /tg/ is arguing over mostergirl mating and which way rivers are supposed to flow, we're here to help you turn your thoughts into an actual finished product.

As the successor to the Storythreads, we're also open to /tg/ related fanfiction (D&D, Warhammer, Battletech, whatever). In fact, if you've written any vaguely /tg/-related short stories, you can try them out here. We also have flash-fiction challenges from time to time.

There's a discord for writers here
https://discord.gg/6AwKHGF

The previous thread can still be found in the archive here
>>86799881

And finally an archive of /tg/ fiction can be found here:
http://1d4chan.org/wiki/Storythread

name: Anonymous
com:
How do you you make gods in your worlds?
What type of pantheon do your prefer? monotheistic, dualistic, polytheist?
If there are multiple gods how are their relation to one another? family like, rivalry, open war, or just don't care?
Are your gods a presence in everyday life or just the thing of speculation and legend?
Do each race in your world worship their own god or are gods something that is beyond race?
What does your gods represent? something abstract like good, evil, order, chaos or something more grounded like war, smiting, agriculture?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86982042, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)19:48:38', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'I don't have traditional gods in my world, at least not in the sense of a codified list of names of gods and their domains and all that.
There are "spirits", instead, sort of primordial elementals or egregores that embody specific concepts. If something exists, there's probably someone who reveres its spirit. They don't have any personification or real appearance, but they do answer prayers, ect. (Clerics are still a thing, after all.)
If a player wants to play a religious character, I have them write in the "religion" box on their sheet what spirits they hold in especially high regard. It's totally freeform, as there exist many spirits as things that exist. The Cleric in my current game especially reveres the spirits of Inertia and Mass.', 'time': 1670633318, 'resto': 86918177}, {'no': 86982294, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)20:24:12', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86982025

com: Is it possible to have Tzeentch, Khorne, or Nurgle Eldar? Like, say an Eldar tries to escape Slaanesh’s attention by worshipping a different Chaos god.
last_replies:
[{'no': 86985093, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)02:27:40', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86982122
There are Chaos Eldar, although I don't think it was ever made clear whether they all serve Slaneesh and haven't been eaten for some reason or if they swore allegiance to one of the other gods to avoid getting nommed. It's sufficiently enjoyable to be worth playing with the right group. If you dialed down the Annihilator value or size you could probably make it even cheaper.', 'time': 1670627912, 'resto': 86892295}, {'no': 86981339, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)18:26:58', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86981223
I sometimes forget that set hate exists.

Imagine if shit like that was still happening. Do you think it would turn into part of sideboard meta in Standard?', 'time': 1670628418, 'resto': 86892295}, {'no': 86982635, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:07:53', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86981339
If it was anything that drastic, maybe. It would depend a lot on how many decks there are that hinge off of a particular wincon or combo piece from that set, and if it's a good set, you're probably screwing yourself over if you deliberately exclude the cards from your deckbuilding so your own hate piece doesn't turn it off.

It's not exactly a great mechanic, since for it to be worth using, it would have to shut down your opponent's deck pretty heavily, but in the cases where it works, you're just turning it into a non-game. Punishing people for not running a wide enough variety of cards from different standard sets isn't exactly healthy for the game, unless there's one set which is vastly better than the rest, which is a bigger issue.
It also might cause some confusion, since if you go by updated City in a Bottle wording, it only cares about original printing, so any reprints WotC made for the set would be excluded, which means newer players would probably end up having to look up if a particular card is a reprint or not.', 'time': 1670638073, 'resto': 86892295}, {'no': 86983580, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)22:47:07', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'I'm chipping away at building a custom set. name: Anonymous
com:
Big Haul Edition

>What is Genesys?
Released in November 2017, Genesys is a pen-and-paper generic/universal RPG system and toolkit by Fantasy Flight Games and EDGE Studio, using a refined version of the system presented by their Star Wars RPGs (Edge of the Empire, Age of Rebellion, Force and Destiny). Its central mechanic is the Narrative Dice System, using pools made of specialized dice to create narrative results. The intention is for the system to be a highly flexible narrative system, adaptable to most any conceivable setting and premise.
https://www.fantasyflightgames.com/en/products/genesys/
https://edge-studio.net/

((LATEST NEWS))
>EDGE Studio is currently prioritizing digital releases so as not to be held up by more difficult physical releases

Not just the spells, but certain spell mods are exclusive to different schools. For example, only Divine can add the Holy/Unholy mod to Attack spells (dealing damage to a target the GM determines is the antithesis of your faith does +2 damage per success instead of +1), while Arcana gets the Manipulative mod (may spend 1 advantage to forcibly move the target one range band) and Primal gets Non-Lethal (add the Stun Damage quality).', 'filename': '1560483473370', 'ext': '.jpg', 'w': 650, 'h': 1174, 'tn_w': 69, 'tn_h': 125, 'tim': 1670631046330248, 'time': 1670631046, 'md5': 'XAgjgOYOyPAs4MfvoTESmg==', 'fsize': 545068, 'resto': 86923567}, {'no': 86981708, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)19:13:19', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86981270
>Also, is there some kind of system in place that provides progress trackers and mechanics that make them progress? Or is that something I'd have to hack in?
I don't quite follow. Can you elaborate?', 'time': 1670631199, 'resto': 86923567}, {'no': 86982759, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:19:45', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86981708
Sounds a lot like Ironsworn's Vows mechanic. You have a row of 10 boxes, and each "quest" or thing to be accomplished (bond with a character, combat, etc.) is assigned a difficult (from five tiers, so it meshes with Genesys nicely). The harder it is, the less of the box you fill in when you succeed. When you're read to complete the question, you roll "against" the progress bar. You don't actually have to fill it, and instead the more you complete the more likely you are to close out the quest successfully.

As far as Genesys is concerned, this is just a skill challenge by another name.', 'time': 1670638785, 'resto': 86923567}, {'no': 86982768, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:20:55', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86982759

In both of these outcomes your franchise is being molded into the shape Hollywood deems for it by writers, directors and investors who have never even heard of it, with the only difference being whether or not that influence was isolated to the movie or if that touch irreversibly tainted the source original material via the devs trying to capitalize.

>You think it has to do with how difficult the lore or source material might be for mainstream audiences unlike DnD?
It's because the lore is basically all there is in 40k, even the "story" and "narratives" are only cared about by fans as extensions of the lore. DnD is really an associated series of fantasy tropes and reductive concepts, which makes it ideal for adapting a movie, you can make basically whatever you want with it and people who don't know about DnD can still enjoy it. People who already like DnD don't all share the same knowledge of the same lore because DnD doesn't have one big setting, it has lots of settings and people constantly make their own (though they are usually highly derivative even by the standards of fantasy). 40k on the other hand is no longer used as a big setting to tell myriad stories in (it may have been once but isn't anymore), the primary interaction people have with 40k, and the aspect people enjoy most is immersion in the lore/setting by reading wiki articles and watching videos on youtube. What stories 40k has are pretty awfully written, always extremely arch and trite so there's not much specific of any value to adapt from either. A movie isn't going to replicate the things about 40k that people really like the most because they like the vast grimdark setting. Whereas DnD people like to play out stories in which a group of 3-6 characters go on fantasy adventures, which is already most fantasy movies
>Or is it maybe a similar case to that of the Amazon's Conan the Barbarian show considering the heavy militaristic themes and such?
This is a factor, but given 40k's extreme popularity (which lets be honest is greater than conan's now) it seems like theyd just try to change things to fit', 'time': 1670641183, 'resto': 86982350}, {'no': 86983769, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)23:10:39', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86982350

name: Anonymous
com:
Skills in most non-D&D games can usually be placed in the following categories:
>Social skills
>Mental skills
>Physical skills
>Combat skills
Speaking from a purely practical perspective and assuming you have no idea what's going to happen during the campaign, In which order would the ideal player character seek to maximize them, assuming he plays alone and doesn't try to be a jack of all trades (ie being shit at all of them simultaneously)?

name: Anonymous
com:
How do you solve the trolley problem when it comes up in-game in some form? Do you desperately try to find another path that saves everyone? Do you make the choice to walk away?

Trolley problems can sometimes be subtle. The players and even the GM might not realize that the current situation qualifies as a trolley problem. Anything that involves choosing which people to save, or trading the well-being of one group for the well-being of a different group, could be a trolley problem.

What are some trolley problems you have encountered in actual games? How have you solved them?

name: Anonymous
com:
Does anyone else despise purely passive/reactionary abilities and skills? I mean the stuff that you can't do a single thing with until the GM explicitly prompts you to roll them. Every fucking system is riddled with this shit.
>health/endurance skill
>defense/dodge skill
>awareness skill
>social/mental resistance skill
It's like a tax on staying alive. I hate it. I make a point of dumping them as hard as possible in favor of skills that I can actually do stuff with. So what if my character dies? At least I got to do stuff while he was alive.

What group-based RPGs have mechanics that you don't get to use? Even PoET or Ironsworn have mechanics the use of which is limited by circumstance. "Whenever your character does X" is literally the "GM" telling you when you to a bunch of mechanics.

I don't this argument makes sense.', 'time': 1670616380, 'resto': 86957059}, {'no': 86980873, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)17:25:56', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86979586
Languages and tools from d&d 5e. Played for years, used them.. maybe once, I think.
> but that’s on the GM for not present opportunities for their use
Well that’s the point, isn’t it? The system doesn’t really have a clue what to do with the rule, so it offloads responsibility to the GM. That doesn’t mean they can’t or won’t find ways to incorporate them, but a system that’s conscious of its own procedures is less likely to have that kind of redundancy.

For an egregious example (that’s more in line with what I think OP is talking about), take perception-based skills; specifically 3e’s Spot and Listen. They’re separate from Search (which is the actually proactive one), and increase your chance of seeing or hearing traps/assassins/secrets - things that are entirely decided by the gm. And in fact, the gm is encouraged to make the roll for the player, to avoid the meta of knowing you rolled like shit. After character creation (not including any further improvements), the utility of those skills are entirely out of the players’ hands.

I totally get what the above is in aid of (verisimilitude), but without doing the smart thing and giving it an additional active use, it just feels like
> a tax on staying alive', 'time': 1670624756, 'resto': 86957059}, {'no': 86980987, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)17:39:37', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86968333

I was being brief for simplicity, but I mean "doesn't really exist" in the sense of "isn't a well-defined concept that can be consistently applied without an arse-mad definition to beat over someone's head". Like, sure, you can say that "strengths" is one syllable in technical terms, but I'd wager that everyone in my accent (Estuary English) treats it as two—/stɹɛŋ.kθs/ (bit like Czech, though my memory was that it only allows that with liquids like /r/?). That's not to say it's a syllable as far as academic linguistics is concerned, just as far as the layman supposes. I personally see the layman's idea more relevant here; we should be dealing with things 'as they are', not as we 'want them to be'.

To illustrate my meaning, let's say you were trying to teach someone the word. A common way to do so is to say the word slowly and have the person copy you after each word-fragment. For instance, the word "discombobulate" is broken down into /dis kom bob ju lait/. Speakers with my accent would almost certainly go with /streŋ θs/ (the /k/ is weakened to non-existence when speaking slowly). Conversely, "asked" would just be /askd/, maybe /ask:d/ if really trying to hammer the point home. So, while an academic linguist would say "one syllable for both", the poet, who is not a phonotactician, wouldn't be so prescriptive.

To further hammer the point home, "realised" would actually be four syllables according to my primary school teachers (who, like the poet, adhere to 'naturally spoken breaks' as opposed to strict CV boundaries): /ri:.a.lai.zd/. The fact of the matter is that Japanese has none of this ambiguity or contention because its syllables ARE well-defined!', 'time': 1670649630, 'resto': 86931037}, {'no': 86984264, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)00:22:05', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86983715

name: Anonymous
com: At what point is it not a dick or fun ruining move to introduce consequences for violating the masquerade/other similar rules? It’s obviously overreacting for the feds to get involved over one report of what looked like someone drinking the blood of a hooker but what about a community all talking about how a group of teens saw a wolf walking on their hind legs?
last_replies:
[{'no': 86978742, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)13:28:09', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86978176
Were you planning this as an unexpected "gotcha" moment from the start? Can work if you know (by knowing the player, or from your pitch conversation) that they would be on board with it.

Is the player new, new to you, or did the whole "masquerade" thing maybe not land in their head? Ask them, out of character, what they and their character know about the masquerade, how much they think they breached it, and what they think the consequences would be. Use their reaction to gauge.

Also, is the game set in a year when funny animal clips and doctored videos are plentiful and easily accessible.', 'time': 1670610489, 'resto': 86978176}, {'no': 86980734, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)17:09:07', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86978742
Game hasn’t started yet but I’ve been freaking out over now to handle it so I figured I’d ask /tg/. Game is modern day with no gotcha planned.', 'time': 1670623747, 'resto': 86978176}, {'no': 86982733, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:17:03', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86978176
There should ALWAYS be consequences, just keep the consequences proportional.', 'time': 1670638623, 'resto': 86978176}, {'no': 86982806, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:25:10', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86980734
So, assuming you don't know your players very well: before their first session as vampires, ask them what they know of it or if they have any experience with it. During the game, tell them where the line is, how to fix it, and what the consequences are.

>a dick or fun ruining move
That's more about group dynamic and flow of play than about the masquerade. Generally, you want a player to be aware that a course of action might risk the masquerade (and what they'll have to clean up) before they commit to it.

If you're asking for what level of response suits what level of breach, I don't know. You could see if there's a WoD thread up.', 'time': 1670639110, 'resto': 86978176}, {'no': 86984656, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:22:32', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86978176
>a group of teens
Drugs. Detain and search them all, call the parents.', 'time': 1670653352, 'resto': 86978176}]

com:
What games do you consider "lifestyle games" from the modern Era?

By Lifestyle, I do not mean chasing a market like TCG titles or having to update armies and such to be viable like most Wargaming stuff. I am aware a lot of one's life can revolve around those evolving genres, however, I am referring to stand-alone games that offer a level of complexity/strategy/tactics that one could dedicate the bulk of their free time playing them and STILL find interesting moves/setups/combos/etc that they didn't see before.

Pic kinda related. Has all the trappings needed to be one, but is far too complex for most to even attempt.

name: Anonymous
com:
I want to run a superhero campaign, probably masks, where the first few sessions are very normal for the genera. Then about five sessions in things take an extremely dark turn, something eldrich is realesed and the world is thrown into an apocalypse.
The players are put in suspended animation. When they awaken they're in a brutal post apocalyptic world with no way back. Their only option being to try to continue their mission of protecting people now in a twisted and horrific version of the world they once knew.

The players would not be let in on any of this beforehand. They'd just think it would be a normal superhero game.
last_replies:
[{'no': 86977368, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)10:10:18', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86944422
Doesn't sound like a terrible idea, but you should test the waters a bit beforehand. In one of the early sessions do a dark, but still established superhero plot and see how they react. If they don't like the darker elements of your knock off Death in the Family or Snowbirds Don't Fly then they probably won't enjoy the bigger twist either.', 'time': 1670598618, 'resto': 86944422}, {'no': 86977790, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)11:10:52', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': 'I love the idea personally, and as a player I can be inclined to roll with the punches, but that's probably because I almost only ever GM anyway. I would warn the players that there's a dark twist/genre change of some sort part way in. Player buy in is super important with GM shenanigans IMO.', 'time': 1670602252, 'resto': 86944422}, {'no': 86977891, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)11:25:06', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86944839
I'm normally inclined to agree with you 100%, but I've got a couple of ideas off the top of my head that might make OP's idea work. Just spit balling, feel free to call me gey and tell me it wouldn't work. Firstly he could do something like the time travel from the new Lightyear movie, where the PCs effect a time jump in a spaceship during a mission or something and come back to a post-apocalyptic setting. Secondly, and I say this second because I'm not as certain of how to make it work, but it could be something like the Megaman Zero GBA games. PCs are entered into suspended animation, but are abruptly reawakened post-apocalypse by a member of some surviving faction needing their help. Maybe they're being loaded on a spaceship in suspended animation for some kind of mission, but the apocalypse happens shortly thereafter and they remain in cryosleep for a hundred years. Or maybe they voluntarily go to sleep like in the game, but in that idea that should be part of character creation and OP should scrap the earlier sessions of ordinary superhero genre stuff.

In either case, it would be good if the conditions of entering suspended animation (or whatever they were doing before going to sleep) was related somehow to what they'll be doing when they wake up. It's also pretty much mandatory that the players have some buy in to OP's actual game, not just for a lighthearted superhero game.', 'time': 1670603106, 'resto': 86944422}, {'no': 86982860, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)21:29:47', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86977891

Mazinger zero is honestly too convoluted to explain, so I won't.

Getter Emperor is, in the shortest possible form, basically an evil TTGL that happens to be helping the protagonists. Its an energy source called Getter Energy that told a scientist how to use it to power a weapon of war that continues to create more Getter Energy, and the more power it has the more transformations and evolutions it undergoes. We see visions of a future where Getter Emperor, the biggest and strongest version of Getter we have seen, is wiping out every form of life in the universe that isn't humans, and it only likes humans because we built the original Getter Robo and continue to serve as its army. It is widely believed that Getter Emperor will eventually destroy the universe itself entirely, even its loyal humans. But even in the 'modern' timetime Getter Energy does crazy magical bullshit like turn Mars into a garden world in like an hour by just rewriting the planet.
tldr: Getter wants humans to succeed because we are in a symbiotic relationship with it by sheer fucking luck, it could just as easily have been someone else who made Getter first and the tables would have been turned. But even in a best case scenario we rule the universe only to be the last ones to die.
