name: Anonymous
com:
So I've been playing around with GPT trying to come up with a sci-fi space opera like setting for a RPG I would like to create. I think what I got here might actually be kinda interesting mind you some of it has been edited and changed from the AI. So here goes.
The game take place on a world called Phillion. Phillion is a young Earth like alien world and is 2nd planet within its solar system. Two tidally locked moons Eopi and Denebola on roughly opposite sides of Phillion keeps the planets natural axial tilt stabilized. Unlike Earth a day on Philion is 26 hours but retains the same distinct seasons abit with a slightly higher average global temperature. Phillion is the home to diverse fauna as birds, reptiles which leads to speculation that life may have been seeded on this world from Earth in the distant past. The only sentient species on Phillion is a humanoid cat like race natives called the Phillions (who the planet is named after) and vaguely resemble cat girls/boys of anime and fantasy on Earth and have a long spanning culture, language and civilization stretching thousands of years.
There are four major factions/nations on this world.

The Bygeniou State- One of the two human colonist originating nations. A ruthless and highly militaristic society that values strength, discipline and power above all else. They are the largest Nation by numbers and territory.

The Phillion Republic- A new nation comprised of native peoples of Phillion. Prior to it's creation the Phillions were a tribal people that were enslaved by the Vatallus but manged to stage a mass revolt and regain their freedom but only at a great cost.

The Arlington Federation- The other human nation. The Arlington Federation value freedom and individual liberty above all else. They technically the only true democracy in the world of Phillion and were once apart of the same alliance as the Bygeniou.

The Vatallus Empire- A bizarre ancient beyond reckoning alien race that once enslaved the Phillions.
last_replies:
[{'no': 86984540, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:08:04', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86984457
I have the backstory for the Phillions
The native peoples of Phillion existed on their world since time immemorial and were once a glorious, thriving tribal civilization. They enjoyed a prosperous golden age of arts, science and culture that most other species could only dream of. That all changed the dark day the angular sharp black green ships of Vattallus Empire descended from the skies. The Vattallans seeing the Phillions as savage and primitive embarked on a full scale planetary invasion. Despite having promising initial gains and victories over the Vattallus at first, the Phillions were not united at time and were defeated. With the Vattallans victorious the Phillions were subsequently enslaved and brought to the brink of extinction. For the next 1,000 years the Vattallus ravaged much of planets resources and used the Phillions as slave labor and test subjects. Centuries later at the same exact time humans crashed onto Phillion a massive astronomical event disabled much of the Vattallus technology. Seizing this opportunity for freedom the Phillions staged a massive revolt won their freedom defeated the Vatttalus and drove their remnants into hiding in deep space. However this rebellion came at a great cost. The once great Phillion Civilization was in tatters and countless lives were paid in what was ultimately a hollow victory.
Should I go on?', 'time': 1670652484, 'resto': 86984457}]

>/tg hates it because it's collaborative storytelling.
/tg/ hates it for many reasons, but collaborative storytelling is only part of one of the many problems. More specifically, PbtA games are BAD collaborative storytelling. It's done in a shitty way that is mechanically unengaging and boring. Anything PbtA jerks itself off about doing is something anyone can do with any system if they felt like it.', 'time': 1670650140, 'resto': 86976058}, {'no': 86984512, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:04:18', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86978881
I have a group of friends I've been playing since the 80s, and two others I've been playing for the last few years. Yes I'm old, fuck you.
Half the seasons we don't roll dice. But when we do we want to know why and what the result is and also be able to do more than rely on luck.
Most storytelling systems are bad for that. PbtA has no levels of success, and barely any modifiers. You aren't better than another character at something. You're just lucky. WoD is just a repeated coin toss (I like V20 because the TN isn't number of 6+ but the number on the dice). I hate d100 systems or roll under your stat systems. I'm not competing against myself to hit the opponent. Nobilis doesn't work because you can never fail nor succeed, simply "succeed with an issue". No tension. Same with Genesys, the SW/L5R one. Too many times are you in a situation where you succeed, but not quite. You never feel like you've actually accomplished anything before you get tossed into another issue. That's not on the DM. That's the system.
And yet one of my favorite systems is CoC. It works because the settings works. You can't fight what you're facing, and when you fight what you can you'll probably end up dead. And the rest is fine for the setting as well, since you're the one noticing (ever looked directly at a set of keys and didn't see them?). But take the system into something generic and it fails.
It depends how it's done, and they can be done well. But, like traditional RPGs, most storytelling systems don't work outside a very narrow set of ideas.
All that said, STILL not as bad as simulation games. Are you the type that enjoys spreadsheets and inane amounts of detail? Do you want to look up results for every roll? Do you want your character to die after getting cut because the dice decided you got tetanus?

That's my 2 CP.', 'time': 1670652258, 'resto': 86976058}, {'no': 86984544, 'now': '12/10/22(Sat)01:08:41', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86983999
It can't. It's 2d6 (with a range between -1 and +3 based on your playbook, and any other bonuses or penalties are never mentioned or actively discouraged by the games themselves) with predetermined success rates. Before you say "homebrew it", no shit. In that case any system is good. But we're not talking homebrew, we're talking RAW.

>>86984190
They're storytelling games. They're not RPGs though. But they are, by definition, games. If you enjoy that, good on you.', 'time': 1670652521, 'resto': 86976058}]

wut', 'time': 1670645175, 'resto': 86974094}, {'no': 86983937, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)23:31:00', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86978272
>>86980951
For reference, since I think we just had that thread, there is the 'Official' Fallout RPG from Modiphius. It's based on their 2d20 system updated to include SPECIAL stats, levels, skills, etc. from the Bethesda games. Yes the setting is Fallout 4, with all the ideas, items, and creatures from that game. Emphasis on the items, as they really went all out with the scavenging, crafting, gear, etc. and it makes up the majority of the book.
You'll hear a lot of negative things about the game, but the 2d20 system is just fine at worst, and they did a good job modifying it to capture playing the 3D Fallout games (for better or worse). A lot of the negatives about the game are actually just about the core rulebook, and the awful job they did editing & proofreading it. Very rushed, typos, errors, and omissions from changed rules; feels like they had the "end-of-playtesting-beta" copy and instead of giving it one last proofread just shipped it (the official .pdf is/was borked too). They also cut out some random bits of rules (for scavenging) and put them in the GM materials.

People will also complain about the proprietary dice, but at the risk of being called a shill I think that's one of the least offensive things a game company could do at this point. The Fallout dice are particularly innocuous: there's a D20 which is just the hit location table on a die, and the others are D6 that break down as follows: 1=1, 2=2, 3/4=miss, and 5/6=1+ bonus effects.
The only thing the game really needs is a fully errata'd core .pdf, and for them to speed up releasing source books including a California/Nevada book. However Bethesda apparently has them in a draconian ballgrip, and is very specific in controlling the Fallout aesthetic they've 'developed,' which has slowed the release (and may have led to the rushed core book).
So IMHO while the materials suffer, the core game is perfectly fine if you want to do some Fallout roll-playing w/out building on another system.', 'time': 1670646660, 'resto': 86974094}, {'no': 86984118, 'now': '12/09/22(Fri)23:55:39', 'name': 'Anonymous', 'com': '>>86974094
The Modiphiüs fallout system is really good, and all the models they use for Wasteland Warfare are compacompatible', 'time': 1670648139, 'resto': 86974094}]
